Legal_Issue: Whether Nandre met the residency requirement under s. 5(1) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Nandre was absent from Canada for significant periods but maintained property ownership and tax payments
Court_Ruling: The appeal is allowed due to failure to determine when residence was established
Defendant_Behavior: Maintained ties to Canada despite prolonged absences
Grounds_for_Claim: Failure to establish timeline of Canadian residence
Legal_Standard: Three years of residence in the previous four years
Assessment_Factor: Physical presence vs. qualitative connection to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Insufficient reasoning by Citizenship Judge on establishment of residence
Evidence_Used: Property ownership records, tax payment records
Evidence_Assessed: Ties to Canada despite physical absence
Governing_Rule: Residence interpreted as physical presence or strong connection
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to specify when residence was established
Outcome: Citizenship application disallowed pending proper assessment
Harm_Assessment: Risk of granting citizenship without meeting legal requirements
Cause_Description: Nandre's citizenship application was approved despite questionable fulfillment of residency requirement
Evidence_Handling: Considered but insufficiently analyzed regarding timing of residence
Evidence_Issues: Lack of clarity on when residence was established
Evidence_Assessment: Incomplete evaluation of residence establishment date
Decision_Rationale: Critical to determine when residence was established to assess compliance with s. 5(1)
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to address when residence began
Legal_Standard_Applied: Qualitative and physical tests for residence
